name: Sfenj (Maghrebi Doughnuts)
name_origin: The name is derived directly from the Arabic word 'isfanj' (سفنج), meaning 'sponge', referring to the dough's porous, airy interior texture when fried. The Arabic term itself is a loanword from the Ancient Greek 'spongos' (σπόγγος). In Maghrebi dialects (Tunisian Derja and Moroccan Darija), the initial vowel is dropped, resulting in 'Sfenj'. The Hebrew form provided, 'Sfinjot' (שפינג׳ות), is a Judeo-Arabic hybridization, applying the Hebrew feminine plural suffix '-ot' to the Arabic noun.
description: Traditional North African deep-fried yeast doughnuts. These rustic fritters have a spongy interior and a crispy exterior, typically eaten plain or sprinkled with sugar.
cultural_context: A staple street food in Morocco and Tunisia. In Jewish tradition, Sfenj are widely consumed during Hanukkah to celebrate the miracle of the oil, and are also a popular breakfast or tea-time treat.

steps.instruction: Prepare the dough: Mix flour, yeast, salt, and warm water to create a soft, sticky dough. Knead well.
steps.tips: The dough should be much wetter than bread dough.

steps.instruction: Cover and let the dough rise in a warm place until it doubles in volume.
Heat deep oil in a wide pan.
Once the dough has risen, grease your hands with oil or water. Take a piece of dough (about the size of a tennis ball), stretch it gently to create a ring or rustic shape.
steps.tips: Wet hands prevent the sticky dough from clinging to you.

steps.instruction: Place carefully into the hot oil and fry until golden brown on both sides.
Remove from oil and drain. Optionally sprinkle with sugar while hot.

variants.name: Sfenj bil Asal
variants.description: Dipped in honey instead of sugar.

variants.name: Sfenj with Egg
variants.description: A Tunisian variation where an egg is fried inside the center of the dough ring.

name_etymology.notes: Standard etymology in Arabic linguistics. The connection to Greek 'spongos' is well-documented in dictionaries of Arabic loanwords. The texture comparison to a sea sponge is literal.

alternative_names.name: Khfaf
alternative_names.notes: Means 'the light ones', referring to the airy texture; common in Algeria and parts of Tunisia.

alternative_names.name: Bambalouni
alternative_names.notes: A specific Tunisian variant (often ring-shaped) derived from the Italian 'Bomboloni'. While similar, Bambalouni are often associated with street vendors in Sidi Bou Said, whereas Sfenj is the traditional home/rustic term.

alternative_names.name: Ftair
alternative_names.notes: Sometimes used interchangeably in Libya, though Ftair can also refer to flatbreads.

similar_dishes.name: Buñuelos
similar_dishes.similarity: Fried yeast dough often eaten with sugar.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Buñuelos are often smaller, rounder fritters rather than the large rings or rustic discs of Sfenj.

similar_dishes.name: Zalabia
similar_dishes.key_difference: Zalabia is typically made from a wet batter (poured) rather than a stretchable dough, and is soaked in syrup rather than dusted with sugar.

similar_dishes.name: Lokma
similar_dishes.key_difference: Much smaller, bite-sized spheres soaked in heavy syrup.

similar_dishes.name: Sufganiyot
similar_dishes.key_difference: Sufganiyot are round, filled with jelly/custard, and contain eggs/butter, whereas traditional Sfenj is a lean dough (flour, water, yeast) and unfilled.

intro_paragraph: Sfenj—derived from the Arabic word for "sponge"—are rustic, deep-fried yeast doughnuts known for their airy, porous texture. These golden fritters are typically enjoyed hot, either plain or dusted with sugar. A staple North African street food, they hold special significance in Jewish homes during Hanukkah, celebrating the miracle of the oil.
